content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple pieces of tissue. At least four distinct, ovoid to lobulated structures with dense, dark purple (basophilic) staining are present, which are characteristic of lymph nodes. Other larger, more irregular tissue fragments consist of adipose tissue (fat), fibrous stroma, and some epithelial components, likely representing sections from the primary tumor and/or surrounding pericolic fat. The overall impression is a slide from a colorectal cancer resection containing multiple lymph nodes for staging.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

A pathologist must be systematic and examine every piece of tissue on the slide, no matter how small. The green box highlights a very small, isolated tissue fragment on the far left. While it's easy to focus on the larger, obvious lymph nodes, these small fragments can harbor crucial findings like isolated tumor deposits or a completely replaced micrometastatic lymph node. The slightly dark appearance of this speck at low power is suspicious and necessitates a high-power examination to rule in or out the presence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is a clearly identifiable lymph node (the second distinct lymph node/nodular cluster from the top). In a cancer staging case, every lymph node must be meticulously examined for evidence of metastasis. This particular node is very dark and hypercellular, which could represent either a benign reactive process (e.g., follicular hyperplasia) or complete replacement by tumor cells. Therefore, a high-magnification view is essential to assess the cellular morphology and architecture to make this distinction. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The zoom is on the largest, most complex piece of tissue, which I suspect is the primary tumor. The selected area is at the interface between a cluster of basophilic cells and the surrounding adipose tissue. I would zoom into this specific location to assess the tumor's invasive front. My goal is to determine if the tumor is invading into the pericolic/perirectal adipose tissue, which is a key factor for determining the pT stage (e.g., pT3). I am looking for irregular nests or single malignant cells within the fat. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a small cluster of atypical, malignant glandular structures. The glands are irregular in shape, some appear fused, and they are composed of cells with large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This morphology is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. There is no discernible residual lymph node tissue. My impression is that this is a tumor deposit (a satellite nodule of cancer in the pericolic fat separate from the primary tumor), which is a significant finding for staging (pN stage). This is a positive finding for metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense, diffuse infiltrate of lymphoid cells. The vast majority of the cells are small, mature-appearing lymphocytes with round, dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. The cells are arranged in ill-defined nodules. I do not see the characteristic features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as atypical glandular structures, nests of large epithelial cells with vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli, or extensive necrosis. Instead, the features are consistent with a reactive lymph node, possibly showing follicular hyperplasia. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis in this field of view.
This is ROI 3. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see nests of malignant glandular cells, characteristic of adenocarcinoma, on the upper left. These tumor cells are directly adjacent to and infiltrating the mature adipose tissue (fat cells). This confirms tumor invasion into the fat. The large white area contains significant out-of-focus artifacts (floaters), which should be ignored. The key finding is the presence of tumor in adipose tissue, which, if this is the primary tumor site, would contribute to a pT3 staging.
